awd_titl_txt: CEDAR: Characterizing Electron Loss to the Atmosphere Using Multi-point Measurements From Riometers and Spacecraft
awd_abstract_narration:
The Coupling, Energetics, and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions (CEDAR) program, a broad-based, community-guided, upper atmospheric research program, is aimed at understanding the behavior of atmospheric regions from the lower atmosphere upward through the ionized upper layers of the atmosphere and into the magnetosphere region of outer space. The research funded by this award would analyze the absorption data collected over the past 25 years by a network of 13 riometers located distributed across central Canada with a typical spatial separation of 500 to 2000 km between adjacent sites.  These instruments operate at 30 MHz and measure at multiple locations the signal absorption of extraterrestrial cosmic noise radiowave caused by electron production in the altitude range of 75 to 115 km (upper D- and lower E-regions).  Two sources of electron production exist in this height range: 1) photoionization and 2) impact-ionization associated with the precipitation of ions and electrons of magnetospheric origin.  The loss of the radiowave power received above the Earth's surface at any one time relative to a Quiet Day Curve (which is associated with photo-ionization) is a measure of the absorption to be associated with the precipitation of particles into this ionized region. Calibration of the riometer absorption measurements would be achieved by using measured fluxes of precipitating electrons and measured populations of trapped electrons observed in the radiation belts. This calibration would be based upon the magnetosphere detector measurements derived from tracing the positions of satellite particle energy detectors onboard the Van Allen Probes and the five THEMIS satellites using a sophisticated field-line model of the Earth's magnetic field distribution to determine the magnetospheric footprints of these satellites in situ measurements at various spatial locations across central Canada.  The process of selection of riometer absorption data for this calibration process would extract those absorption values associated with the coincidence of the footprint positions with the riometer field of view. The riometer absorption data collected would be analyzed in a statistical sense to establish possible causal relationships between the absorption signature regarding size and shape of absorption and the particular energy band responsible for the particle precipitation into the 90 km region for each riometer site. One relationship that would be searched for in this research is the development of a possible proxy for the extent of magnetospheric wave activity causing the particle precipitation. Another relationship would be the determination from the observed absorption the fractional loss of energetic electrons in the range of tens of keV to MeV energies to the upper atmosphere.  A broader impact of this award would be the enhancement of a riometer network as a useful tool with a strong potential for successful application in terrestrial and space weather forecasting. 

Comparing riometer absorption with satellite measurements of precipitating electrons will provide for the development statistically of a relationship relating the size and shape of riometer absorption signatures with the energy spectrum of the precipitating particles.  The absorption signature results for the different riometers within the network would be used to develop maps of latitudinal and magnetic local time (MLT) distributions of precipitation. Comparison of these signatures with trapped population measurements will quantify the importance of the electron energy loss to the atmosphere, which will help understand the role of energetic electron precipitation in the global system. This study would be coincident with the declining phase of the current solar cycle and will help to demonstrate how low-cost remote sensing of ionospheric precipitation can help understand processes that directly affect the terrestrial and space weather climate.

por.por_cntn:
Riometers are ground-based passive radio receivers that listen to cosmic noise emanating from distant stars and galaxies. Some of the radiowave energy from these galactic sources is absorbed in the Earth’s atmosphere by free electrons, precipitated from electrons trapped by Earth’s magnetic field, and drifting at altitudes above the geomagnetic equator where our weather satellites are in geostationary orbit. This project employed riometer observations, spacecraft observations, and physical modeling, to understand the energy and flux to which the observed radio-wave absorption is responding. The energy and flux are important, as they determine the energy input into the upper atmosphere which has a direct effect on atmospheric chemistry and composition. Utilizing our understanding of how particles move through the Earth’s magnetic field, a drift-time analysis revealed that riometer absorption in the 0.25≤A≤3.0 dB range can be used to remotely infer the existence of drifting electrons of energies 20 to 80 keV, with an increase in CNA corresponding to a non-linear increase in energy. The inferred energy was found to depend on the magnetic field model used, the rise from background during an event or peak absorption, and the magnetic local time (MLT) in which the signal was observed. 

A study utilizing close magnetic field line conjunctions, which link spacecraft observations of electrons to the upper atmosphere, revealed that riometer absorption increases steeply after a threshold of trapped omnidirectional flux is exceeded at 10’s of keV energies. The rate of absorption increase is dependent on MLT, with the highest enhancements occurring near dawn. An investigation of the potential source of this faster rate of absorption revealed that the expected transport of electrons to the upper atmosphere, due to wave-particle interactions with the trapped population, was faster near dawn than near midnight. 

A data-assimilation model, incorporating these new physical properties was employed to show that the flux of 10’s of keV electrons at 600 km above a riometer were consistently higher near dawn and throughout the post-dawn sector, and related to higher values of absorption. These results confirmed that transport of energy to the atmosphere was increased throughout the dawn flank, and was likely due to the faster diffusion rate of electrons, due to the aforementioned wave-particle interactions. At 141 keV and higher, no such clear relationship was found. 

The source of electron precipitation was further investigated using the riometers, wave, and particle instruments from the THEMIS and GOES spacecraft. The aim was to identify a source mechanism responsible for driving the wave-particle interactions that ultimately led to the riometer-observed precipitation. In several events, ultra-low frequency (ULF) wave compressional perturbations were shown to exceed the threshold necessary for generation of very-low frequency (whistler) waves, which were modeled statistically in the aforementioned data assimilative model. The ULF waves were shown to generate quasi-periodic whistler-mode emissions. Utilizing the knowledge that a sufficient trapped flux population is necessary to observe an absorption signal, it was found that the enhanced whistler-mode emissions were sufficiently strong to precipitate electrons into the atmosphere where they exhibited a strong signal in the riometer absorption. This investigation into a physical mechanism responsible for driving precipitation showed that the energy within ULF waves was transferred to whistler-mode chorus, which then interacts with the electrons dissipating the energy into the atmosphere, where it is measurable by the riometers. 

This project has demonstrated that riometers play a crucial role in detecting electron precipitation in the 10’s of keV range. They may also be used to remote sense both the omnidirectional flux of the trapped electron population, and the flux of electrons at 600 km altitude. Finally, riometers play a crucial role in confirming important mechanisms that lead to wave-particle interactions and result in electron precipitation.

A critical step towards the realization of societal benefits, indicated through our broader impacts statements, is to connect with users, whether they are other researchers, government, industry, or the general public. To address this need, the Application Usability Level framework was also developed during the course of this award, which provides a robust method to translate results like those mentioned above into usable models and information to meet the needs of our society.
